content.description: Direct extension to chicken dinner. This route is mega! Once you finish dinner, scope out a good rest in the pod, then do a big reach to a drilled pocket and launch out huge moves on good holds to a another rest before the dyno. Huck your meat to a great jug and embark on a rightward traverse on small holds. The next section is more delicate and balancy which dumps you directly into some very resistant 5.12 climbing on crimps and pockets to the chains. Sick!
content.protection: Fixed draws with lots of dogging draws that can be skipped along the way for the send

content.description: Strap in for this one, 'cause it ain't over 'til it's over. Get off the ground and onto a blank slab. Smear and stem your way up through the first few bolts, slapping your hands around for any vestige of a good handhold and craning your neck to see the feet. Once you pull off the slab, find a good stance and a shake and get ready to tackle the vertical headwall. Balance, sidepull, and crimp your way up through the last three bolts in sustained, technical climbing until the anchors. Clip the chains, rejoice, and take up blood doping before your forearms hurt this bad again.
content.location: Starts on the leftmost side of the Amphitheater, furthest from the trail entrance. Second route from the left, beginning on a bald slab with a vegetated crack running up the left side.

content.description:
Extension to Shiver me Timbers or its own independent line (to the right). Start on either route, SMT seems to be a nicer option with a bouldery sequence down low to jugs.

instead of clipping the anchor clip a bolt on the slab and work your way towards the tiered roof climbing above.  Drilled pockets give way to a crux towards the end and a runout above the last bit for a rightward traverse to the anchor.
content.location: Right side of the crag, goes through noticeable tiered roofs

content.description:
Another wildy steep drilled out route.  This is basically half of Tractor Boy and stops at the pod rest.  Start with the high first bolt, clip the second bolt way behind you and grab the rest you can.  After clipping the third bolt climb the big sequential moves up through bolt 5.  Tackle the crux a few different ways and get another rest at bolt 6 before the pumping finish to the pod.  You are only cool if you sink the kneebar before clipping the bolt!

Get some energy back and keep going on tractor boy!
content.location: starts right of chunder and angles up and right through the cave to the pod rest

content.description: One of the most mega lines at the crag taking a steep line out the cave to a pumping headwall above.  Begin as for tractor girl and rest well at the pod in the roof.  From there follow more drilled pockets to a large rail with poor feet.  A few boulder problems with rests in between will test all your endurance on the beautiful headwall above.
content.location: Follow tractor girl to the pod rest in the ceiling, then straight up and out.  Going left from the pod is New York Jew, 14a

content.description:
Soul Harvester starts on Tractor Girl/boy but cuts right after the 4th bolt and follows 5 more bolts to finish in the ceiling at the end of the long rail.  It's longer than tractor girl but the last bolt is mostly a jug rail the whole way.

For most, the sequence mandates that you decide which route (tractor/soul harvester) you're going to do at the 3rd bolt then forces a right left right or left right left.  Pretty cool!

Expect lots of left heel hooks and not-super-great right feet underneath the rail where it is steeper.
content.location: Begin on Tractor girl on the left side of the cave and it cuts right to follow a long rail feature.

content.description: Starts the same as Walkin' the Plank on the far right side of the crag.  Instead, move leftwards to another bolt line that finishes just after pulling onto the slab.  Bouldery, steeper start, and juggy finish and some slight choss, though nothing broke when we did it
content.location: Right side of the crag.  Right of Gillywrinkle.  look for a route with crazy tiered roofs which is walking the plank.  this goes left

content.protection: Bolts with fixed carabiners at  anchor

content.description: This is the basic warmup in the cave.  Starts in the center of the amphitheater and finishes in a sometimes wet pod with moss around it.  Climbs steeper than it looks
content.protection: 4 bolts, but most only clip the upper 3
content.location: shortest route in the center of the cave

content.description: Last bolt boulder problem, pumpy climbing until there
Climb a low angled slab into a sizable hole (hence the name), where you can get a nice rest, then launch up into great pocket pulling face climbing.
Be prepared to try hard! Fun bouldering to the third bolt leads you to a slab and a good rest out right. Another boulder problem awaites!
content.location: this climb starts on the obvious prow on the right side of the amphitheater sharing the first bolt with Yahtzee and going right.

content.description: A great, short, energy-sapping power route.  Begin with establishing in an undercling rail and either go out left or straight up big move to get to the pod and only rest on the route.  From there, sequential moves on mostly drilled holds get you through the wild crux at bolt 4 and the sustained race to the chains at the ceiling.
content.location: right of lard and left of Boo

content.description: consistent climbing with no real crux moves

Chunder begins on a two-finger pocket for the left hand a drilled handle-like pocket for the right. Stick clip the first (a black hanger) or second bolt (fixed draw), and crank a short boulder problem to a jug at the second bolt. Get a good rest, then fire the next few bolts of long moves on drilled pockets to a brief reprieve mid-cave. Shake here, then launch through the route's three-bolt power-endurance crux, until you reach the jug haul finish of Chicken Dinner. Climb up to the big hole, shake, then traverse left to a no-hands rest in a sizeable pod below the headwall. The character of the route shifts from extremely steep pocket-pulling to delicate, balancey movement on crimps and slopers. Hold it together for the headwall, and you've sent one of the Amphitheater's prize routes.
content.protection: 13 bolts with fixed draws. There is no fixed draw on the first bolt, and you may choose to bring an extra draw to protect the juggy finish of Chicken Dinner.
content.location: Chunder is located on the far left side of the Amphitheater. It is the furthest route to the left with fixed draws. The route climbs up the steepest section of the cave, then veers left onto the headwall.

content.description:
Chicken dinner is a route that stops halfway and is comprised of huge moves on many drilled pockets in a steep permadrawed section of the cave.  Unrelenting moves on drilled jugs, pockets, and edges lead to not-very-difficult crux moves before a final redpoint crux below the yellow rock in the cave. The route finishes at the 8th bolt.  From here continuing onto the headwall it becomes chicken Choker (left, stays at about 13a) or Yellow Man (straight up, 13b)

Didn't feel like there was anything harder than maybe V3 on the whole, the challenge comes from linking it all together.
content.location: starts the same as tractor boy but immediately goes straight up instead of out right.

content.description:
An extension of Chicken Dinner, Chicken Choker fires the headwall above the roof. Once you reach the large hole at the roof's corner (the ninth/anchor bolt of Chicken Dinner), clip the hanging draw to your left that escapes the route via a short traverse (the direct/right line is Yellow Man). Gain a comfortable no-hands stance on somewhat suspect rock and clip the 10th bolt before launching up the headwall. Once you leave the rest, the route climbs solid rock with lots of small edges and slopers reminiscent of Rifle's Anti-Phil wall. You will encounter one shallow, drilled pocket before the chains, but the remainder of the route is natural. Watch for rope drag along the edge of the roof, and be prepared to holler at your belayer when clipping.

Chicken Choker is essentially a link-up of Chunder and Chicken Dinner, sharing the same headwall finish as Chunder.
content.protection: 13 fixed draws to chains (fixed with a single steel carabiner).
content.location: The route starts on Chicken Dinner (left side of the Amphitheater), then extends for four bolts out of the roof onto the headwall. At the ninth and anchor bolt of Chicken Dinner, escape left out of the roof on a short, juggy traverse. The headwall section begins from a comfortable no-hands stance, and follows a series of new chain draws to the top of the cliff.

content.description:
Boo, in my opinion, is probably the most striking and aesthetic line in the Amphitheater.  With a strenuous and resistant start, gentle overhang, roof, and steep headwall, you will need plenty of endurance.

Begin on a section of steep draining drilled pockets for a few bolts.  The angle lessons but continuous movement makes you keep momentum until you hit a large flat jug.  The first real crux is figuring out how on earth you are supposed to get your feet on said jug.  Good luck.

Fun moves lead up to the juggy roof and although the holds are good, it is steep! Above the roof the angle lessons and you are gifted with a huge flat (although fairly sharp) jug.  Rest well here because the real crux is above.

After exiting the rest you eventually move up to a small incut crimp for both hands.  Clip and launch into the slightly runout crux sequence which revolves around a sloping sidupull and a big move to a pinch.  Some airy fall potential provides enough motivation to try a little harder here.  Clip the last bolt and battle a few small crimps to the glory jug at the chains!

The route was originally named "Boo" because of a large tree that I guess you would fall into when you took the big whip off the upper crux.  It was scary so...BOO!
content.location: right of Free Ballin' and left of gillywrinkle and Yahtzee

content.description:
Begin up easy terrain to the left of Hole.  Simple climbing leads up to a large pod with some vegetation nearby.  An old bolt line is left of the shinier new bolts which is what was used before a natural line of climbing revealed itself.  Clip the newer brighter fixe bolts and launch onto a sustained chipped masterpiece.

Sequential moves, no real crux, awesome friendly drilled pockets highlight this route
content.location: right of Whole lotta cotton and left of Hole
